THE HOUSINGSUBSIDY.(previous reference:Cabinet 55(26), Gon-elusion 6.)1, The Cabinet, bad before them Memoranda bythe Minister of Health (Paper CP.-64 (28)) andby the Secretary of State for Scotland (paper c.P.-68 (28)) on the question of a reconsider a-tion of the Housing Subsidy. The Minister ofHealth's Memorandum contained the following proposals:- To adhere to the policy announced in the House of Commons last August that housing subsidies should be got rid of altogether, butthat, with a view to maintaining continuity 33far as possible, this should be done gradually(Para.7): that an all-round reduction equiva-lent to 50 should be made in all Housing Sub-subsidies; that, in the first instance, the dateproposed for the reduction of the subsidy shouldbe the 31st December, 1928, though in the courseof negotiation this might have to be postponedto the 1st October, 1929 (Para.8); that by administrative action- the Ministry of health should endeavour to concentrate the efforts ofthe Local Authorities as far as possible on theprovision of a class of house suitable for theleast well-paid workers; and that the Ministerof Health should inform Local Authorities thatthey may rely on receiving subsidies at thepresent rates in respect of all houses completed by the Slst December, 1928 (Para.9).The Secretary of State for Scotland inhis Memorandum proposed that when the revisionof the Subsidy takes place after the 1st October,1928, so far as Scotland is concerned reductions in Subsidy equivalent to those already imposed in England should take effect as from the date to be fixed in the Order to be then issued; these reductions should he from 6 to 4 perhouse per annum for 20 years in the case ofthe Act of 1923, and from 9 to 7:10:0 (in rural areas from 12:10:0 to 11) in the caseof the Act of 1924 (Para.7). He entered acaveat that when the next revision period(after the 1st October, 1930) arrives his acceptance at the present time of reductionssimilar to those imposed upon England and Walesat the last revision period shall not be held to involve an automatic acceptance of reduc-tions similar to those now proposed by the( Para.8).Minister of Health for England and wales Heconctrrred that the consent of the Local Authori-ties to the 1st October, 1929, as the date uponwhich any proposed reductions should take effect should be obtainable, but expressed preference for the 31st March, 1929, for the first offerInstead of the 31st December, 1928, as proposedby the Minister of Health(para .9) .After hearing statements by the Ministerof Health, the Secretary of State for Scotlandand the Chancellor of the Exchequer, the cabinet agreed (a) To approve the proposals for areduction equivalent to 50 Inthe Housing Subsidy for Englandand Wales, as well as the con-temporaneous reductions proposedby the Secretary of State forScotland:(b) To leave to the Minister of Health,in consultation with the Secretaryof State for Scotland, the decision as to the date to be proposed inthe first instance for the reduc-tion of the subsidy:(c) Subject to the above, to approvegenerally the proposals of theMinister of Health and theSecretary of State for Scotland. BFrTTING.The racecourse betting Bill.The Totalisa-tor.(previous reference:Cabinet 54(27) Con-clusion 4.)2. The Cabinet had before them a Bill to beintroduced by a Private Member (Major Glyn)entitled "The Racecovirse Betting Bill", theobject of which is to authorise as regards race-courses on the days when horseracing takes place under the Rules of the Jockey Club or national Hunt Committee, the use by racecourseauthorities of Totalisators, and the use bybookmakers under the control of such authori-ties of a "place".After considerable discussion, the cabinet agreed (a) To leave the decision on theSecond Reading of the racecourse betting Bill to a free vote ofthe House:(b) That, while Ministers should beas free as other Members of theHouse of Commons in regard totheir vote, and should also be free to take part in the Debate,they should be careful to makeIt clear that they did not commit themselves at this stage to anyparticular detail in the Bill,and they would be well advised to avoid any strong expressjonof opinion in view of the possi-bility that the Government maylater have to give support tothe Bill:(c) That, in the event of the passingof the Second Reading in the Houseof Commons, the question should befurther considered by the Cabinet,and perhaps, in the first instance,by a special Cabinet Committee. The Cabinet had before their, the follow-ing documents relating to the revision of theMilitary Agreement between Great Britain and iraq:-A Note by the Secretary (PaperO.P.-69 (28)), covering -A Letter from the ColonialOffice to the Secretary,Committee of Imperial Defence,covering a draft of the revisedMilitary Agreement (C.I.D. PaperNo. 856-B):An Extract from the Minutes ofthe 233rd Meeting of theCommittee of Imperial Defenceheld on February 16, 1928,containing the following recom-mendations:-(i) That the expression "ground forces", in the third lineof Article 2, should be amended to read "land forces",provided this alterationwould cause no difficulties with the Iraq Government:(ii) That the revised military agreement should be approved subject to the above altera-ti on.The Secretary of State for War drew attention to the fact that, While it wa3 pro-vided in Article 2 that the excess of the costof any Indian forces over their cost if stationed in India would be borne by the Iraq Government,he was not clear as to the vote on which thein Iraqnormal cost of the Indian forces/would fall.It was certain that it was not intended that india should bear the cost, but it was not clear which, of the Home Departments should bear it.On the understanding that the normal costof the Indian Battalions would not fall onArmy Estimates, the Cabinet agreed To approve the revisedMilitary Agreement betweenGreat Britain and Iraq as submitted by the Committeeof Imperial Defence in theConclusions quoted above. The Cabinet had before them a Memorandum(Paper H.A.-I5 (28)) by the Minister of Health,covering a draft Local Authorities (emergency provisions) Bill, 1928, together with theConclusions of the Committee of Home affairs thereon (H.A.C, 4th Conclusions (28)).The Cabinet took note that, in accordancewith the decision of the Cabinet at their meeting on February 15, 1928 (Cabinet 7 (28),Conclusion 9), - f(a) The Committee of Home affairs had approved the Local Authori-ties (Emergency Provisions) Billin the form of the draft annexed to Paper H.A.-13 (28), subjectto certain amendments and any consequential or other drafting alterations that might be neces-sary:(b) That the Bill would be introducedforthwith in the House of Commons,with a view to its passage into law being secured before the 31stMarch, 1928. IRAQ,.The AkhwanRaids .(previous reference:Cabinet 12(28), Con-clusion 2.)5. The Cabinet had before them a joint memorandum by the Secretary of State for theColonies and the Secretary of State for air on the subject of the recent Akhwan Raids(Paper C.P.-70 (28)).The Secretary of State for the colonies and the Secretary of State for Air made state-ments amplifying and confirming their joint memorandum.The Secretary of State for India, refer-ring to reports in the Press to the effect thatIndian troops were to be sent to "Kuweit, informed his colleagues that this information wasincorrect, and that, except in case of the gravest emergency, such action would be impoliticand undesirable, insomuch as the Wahabis wereone of the strictest sects of Moslems.The Secretary of State for the Coloniesreassured the Cabinet that every possibleinfluence was being exerted to deter Sing Faisalfrom plunging Iraq into war with Ibn Saud.The general view of the Cabinet was thatit was desirable that Sir Gilbert Clayton, or,failing him., some other emissary of experience,should, provided it could safely be done, beplaced in touch with Ibn Saud at the earliest-possible moment, with a view to averting anything in the nature of a prolonged struggle, and thatin the meanwhile any attacks on Iraq territory should be repelled. THE BASELTRADINGCOMPANY.(previous cms reference:Cabinet 11(28), Con-elusion 6.)1 *n6. The Cabinet were informed that, afterthe recent Debate in the House of Lords onthe Basel Trading Company, some informal discussion had taken place as to how long theGovernment should be given to try and effect a settlement before the matter was againraised in Debate, and an understanding hadbeen reached that the matter should be post-poned for six weeks. A fortnight had alreadyelapsed and it was becoming Important to reach a settlement.The Secretary of State for India read an extract from a telegram from the Viceroy which made it clear that the Government of India saw no reason for compensating the CommonwealthTrust, which had received valuable propertywithout paying for it and had since madesubstantial profits. In these circumstances the Government of India saw no reason why theyshould accept any liability to the Company, toits staff or to the Directors. There did not seem the slightest prospect that the IndianLegislature would sanction compensation, nor could the Government of India find any argumentswherewith to support it.In the course of the discussion thesuggestion was made that one solution wouldbe to say frankly to the House of Lords, aswell as to the Basel Trading Company, thatHis Majesty's Government were not prepared toput pressure on India, and to suggest that theCompany should approach the Government ofIndia direct. The Cabinet agreed (a) That the question of the BaselTrading Company should bereferred to a -Cabinet Com-mittee composed as follows -The Lord Privy Seal (In the Chair)The Chancellor of the Exchequer(who said he would probably have to be represented byMr Upcott, of the Treasury),The Secretary of State forDominion Affairs,The Secretary of State for India,The Attorney-General,The Parliamentary Under-Secretary,Foreign Office.(b) That the Secretary of State forDominion Affairs should draft,in the strongest possible manner,the arguments which might appealto the Government of India inregard to compensation to theInterests concerned, and should communicate them to the Secretaryof State for India, who undertook to telegraph them to the Governmentof India and to state that theyhad made a favourable impressionupon the Cabinet. All had beenagreed that no second free postage during an election should be allowed.After some discussion the Cabinet agreed -(a) That the question of the maximumscale of expenses at a parliamentary election was one on which theopinion of Parliament could best begathered in the course of the debates on the Bill:(b) -"that, in the first instance, Clause of the Bill attached to Paper C.P.-59 (28), which deals with the maximumscale of expenses at a parliamentary election, should be omitted, althoughit might be necessary to re-inserta Clause of the kind if the Debateshowed a general desire that thematter should be dealt with:(c) Subject to the above, to approvethat the Representation of thePeople (Equal Franchise) Billshould be introduced in the simplestpossible form.2, Whitehall Gardens, S.W.1,March 7, 1928.
